awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: CAS: Upcycling Farm-level Food Waste to Accelerate the Transition to a Circular Economy
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project facilitates the upcycling of farm-level food waste using an innovative technological platform to connect farmers and buyers. Of the more than one hundred million tons of U.S. food waste generated yearly, an estimated twenty percent is comprised of fresh fruits and vegetables wasted at the farm level due to surplus or because the produce does not meet stringent aesthetic sales standards. This project connects farmers to additional buyers for whom aesthetics is not relevant, providing them with lower-cost materials and creating a circular supply chain. This reduction in food going to landfills will decrease methane emissions from landfills. Positive environmental impacts will also be discernible in the communities surrounding landfills through cleaner air, lessened water and soil contamination, and improved human health. As aesthetically imperfect and surplus fruits and vegetables enter the food supply chain, more affordable food will be available, combating food insecurity and promoting social fairness. 

This SBIR Phase I project combines artificial intelligence and a powerful prescriptive analytics engine to build an innovative solution for mitigating farm-level food waste. The project’s primary innovation is creating a material valorization database for customers to access known and new alternative uses for food waste. Verification of saleable produce images will protect customer liability and improve material traceability. Novel custom decomposition optimization will account for produce aging, storage parameters, shipping schedules and consolidation, and transportation logistics to address farm-level supply chain challenges and optimize operations. Carbon-equivalent emissions reductions will also be available for each transaction. Beyond these features, obstacles such as service outages from high customer traffic and poor potential performance from neural networks will also be addressed. The project will address the complexity of large-scale transactions in optimizing farms, buyers, and operation logistics, providing a powerful, vital tool for achieving a circular economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Phase I project successfully showcases the potential of MatLoop, an innovative technology platform aimed at reducing farm-level food waste, fostering sustainable agricultural practices, and unlocking economic opportunities for farmers and businesses. By harnessing advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), prescriptive analytics, and optimization algorithms, MatLoop streamlines produce management, minimizes waste, and generates value from surplus agricultural products across multiple industries.

Key Phase I Achievements

1.     AI-Powered Produce Assessment and Classification
A significant achievement of the Phase I project is developing an AI-powered image processing system designed to evaluate and classify surplus or imperfect produce uploaded to the MatLoop platform. The team trained a deep learning architecture-based AI model utilizing a robust dataset containing images across multiple categories. This system accurately identifies defects such as scarring, discoloration, and decay, enabling farmers and buyers to make informed decisions in real time.

The capability was seamlessly integrated into a user-friendly web interface, facilitating effortless quality verification and efficient marketplace transactions. By delivering transparency and consistency in produce evaluation, the AI tool is vital in fostering trust and reliability between farmers and buyers in the marketplace.

2.     Optimization Engine for Supply Chain Efficiency
The Phase I project showcases the power and functionality of MatLoop's optimization engine. The engine, implemented as an advanced optimization solver, generates optimal routing solutions based on dynamic variables such as truck capacity, produce type, and delivery windows. The solutions enhance logistical efficiency by balancing cost, carbon emissions, and operational effectiveness.

The demonstration scenarios focused on two key logistical strategies:

  • Consolidation Model: Optimizes efficiency by grouping multiple shipments to utilize maximum truck capacity, reducing the number of trips, freight costs, and associated emissions.
  • Backhaul Model: Optimizes efficiency on return trips by transporting additional cargo back to the origin or alternative destinations, preventing empty truck returns and thus boosting profitability.

The backhaul routing strategy yielded impressive results, including a 44% improvement in demand fulfillment (from 61% to 88%), a 20% reduction in shipping costs, and a 25% decrease in CO₂ emissions per unit mass shipped.

3.     Material Valorization Database for Business Innovation
Another significant achievement of the Phase 1 project is developing and integrating a material valorization database into the MatLoop platform. The database leverages AI models to extract relevant insights from patents and scientific journals. This cutting-edge feature enables businesses to discover innovative uses for imperfect and surplus produce across diverse industries, including food and beverage manufacturing, cosmetics, bioenergy, animal feed, and bioplastics.

The platform's backend allows users to search and filter data by product name, chemical components, or intended applications. This functionality empowers businesses to identify opportunities for repurposing food waste into value-added products. For example, the database can recommend transforming banana peels into animal feed or extracting lycopene from tomatoes for cosmetic formulations.

The database aligns with circular economy principles by unlocking creative, sustainable solutions, helping reduce waste, generating value, and promoting environmental stewardship.

Outcomes and Future Directions

The development of the MatLoop platform and its embedded optimization engine, image processing, and valorization database demonstrate the platform's capability to transform the management of farm-level food waste through innovative, technology-driven solutions.

The key Phase I outcomes illustrate MatLoop's transformative potential:

  • Financial Benefits: Optimized logistics reduce freight costs and enhance profitability for farmers and buyers.
  • Environmental Impact: Significant reductions in waste and CO₂ emissions support sustainability goals.
  • Operational Efficiency: Streamlined shipment consolidation and route optimization ensure smooth supply chain operations.

In addition to these results, Phase I emphasized the importance of customer discovery. Feedback from over 140 interviews with farmers, buyers, and stakeholders has provided actionable insights for refining MatLoop's features to align with market needs. These learnings will guide next-phase enhancements to ensure the platform delivers maximum user value.

To ensure MatLoop's commercial success, as Betafeld advances to Phase II, it will continue customer discovery to identify emerging needs and foster market alignment. Alongside refining the optimization engine, expanding the AI dataset, and enriching the valorization database, these efforts will solidify MatLoop's scalability and relevance in diverse agricultural markets.

By addressing critical supply chain challenges with innovative, technology-driven solutions, MatLoop transforms food waste into economic opportunities and promotes global sustainability efforts. The platform is poised to become a scalable, practical tool for fostering sustainable supply chains and driving value from agricultural products.


Last Modified: 03/31/2025
Modified by: Airat Tajudeen-Iwalewa
